definition: Physical or operational characteristics that describe the configuration, state, or technical properties of devices and mechanical systems.

positive_examples: The motor is brushless and operates autonomously.
The device switched from off to on automatically.
The railway uses standard gauge tracks for compatibility.
This backlashless gear system provides precise positioning.
The printer's current state shows it is ready and online.
The autonomous vehicle's sensors are fully operational.
negative_examples: The car's speed increased to 60 mph.
She felt happy about the successful presentation.
The red color of the stop sign was clearly visible.
His personality is very outgoing and friendly.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: PhysicalAttribute, TemporalAttribute, QualityAttribute, RelationalAttribute

opposite_reasoning: PsychologicalAttribute provides the strongest and most useful opposition to DeviceAttrs. It captures multiple complementary dimensions: (1) mechanical/technical vs. mental/emotional, (2) non-sentient vs. sentient, (3) objective-measurable vs. subjective-experiential, (4) physical-device properties vs. psychological-agent properties. For AI safety applications, distinguishing between device-level technical attributes and psychological/mental attributes is crucial for monitoring whether AI systems are being treated as mere tools vs. agents with psychological properties. This opposition has high confidence due to its presence in both WordNet and SUMO, and offers strong semantic distance while remaining conceptually coherent.
